comment.author: 47855139@N03
comment._content: Trinity College dominates straight ahead.  The street curves to the left to go towards O'Connell Bridge over the river Liffey and Oconnell Street, formerly Sackville.  To the right is Grafton Street.

comment.author: 64848937@N00
comment._content: In the foreground is a statue of King George which was often the subject of attack from Nationalists and Republicans.  Following independence the statue was removed from the street and is usually in storage.  I saw it recently and the impact of many attacks is clearly visible as are the various attempts to restore the work.  Nowadays a charming 1960s fountain of the Four Provinces sits on this site.  As Glamborghini notes the facade dominating the view is that of the University of Dublin, Trinity College.  Trinity or TCD is the second largest and the oldest university in Ireland.  It ranks in the top 50 worldwide and has a venerable history that includes Oscar Wilde, Oliver Goldsmith, Dean Swift, Douglas Hyde, Mary Robinson and Samuel Beckett.  The college prides itself on being unorthodox and a place where not being part of the crowd is seen as an asset.  In recent years the college has expanded and grown and a greater focus on pulling in international students and talent as well as world class research has dominated.  Also the university has opened up it's Old Library to visitors so they can see many of the greatest Irish treasures including a Proclamation of the Republic and the greatest treasure of the Celts, the Book of Kells.  Not to be missed either is the Douglas Hyde Gallery, named for Ireland's first president and an institution for cutting edge art.  If you ever get to Dublin try and get a student to show you round the college.

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content:
Glamborghini :

Thanks for the additional information about this photograph.  We will add to the description!

doctorbob:

Thank you for the further information on this image.  From other sources, it does seems this is the statue of King William III, not King George II (formerly found in St. Stephen's Green).  Thanks again for commenting!

comment.author: 64848937@N00
comment._content: Kristi you are 100% correct (my memory is not the best!).  Although to some these kings are all the same.  The great Irish satirist and republican Brendan Behan once defined an Anglo-Irish aristocrat as 'a protestant sitting on a horse'.

comment.author: 59489499@N06
comment._content: Can you tell I like to travel

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Comments with photo of Trinity College in College Square from National Library of Ireland discuss dating clues. Apparently the last horse-drawn tram ran in 1901 and the first electric tram was in 1896. This picture shows no sign of lines for electric trams. Also, the other photo shows a style of electric lamp outside Trinity College that was apparently used between 1892 and 1903. So the photo used as the basis for the photochrom seems likely to be from before 1892.
